abstract.text: Returns one or more keychain items that match a search query, or copies attributes of specific keychain items.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: A dictionary that describes the search. A typical
dictionary consists of:
The item’s class.
Specify the kind of item you want, for example a password, a certificate, or a cryptographic key, using one of the class values in
Attributes.

Narrow the search by indicating the attributes that the found item or items should have. The more attributes you specify, the more refined the results, but not all attributes apply to all item classes. For the attributes applicable to the keychain item you’re searching for, see the entry for the item’s class in
Search parameters.

Condition the search in a variety of ways. For example, you can limit the results to a specific number of items, control case sensitivity when matching string attributes, or search only among a particular set of items. See
for the complete list of possible search parameters.
One or more return types.
Use the keys found in

to indicate whether you seek the item’s attributes, the item’s data, a reference to the data, a persistent reference to the data, or a combination of these. When you specify more than one return type, the search returns a dictionary containing each of the types you request. When your search allows multiple results, they’re all returned together in an array of items.
On return, a reference to the found items. The exact type of the result depends on the return type values supplied in
, as discussed in
A result code. See
By default, this function returns only the first match found. To obtain more than one matching item at a time, specify the search key
with a value greater than
. The
is a
containing up to that number of matching items.
You can’t combine the
and
options when copying password items (items of class
or

), because copying each password item could require additional authentication. Instead, request a reference or persistent reference to the items, then request the data for only the specific passwords that you actually require.
By default, this function searches for items in the keychain. To instead provide your own set of items to filter with the
, specify the search key
and provide as its value a
object containing items of type
, or
. The objects in the provided array must all be of the same type.
To limit a keychain search to a particular keychain or keychains, specify the search key
and provide as its value a
object containing items of type
items.
To convert from persistent item references to normal item references, specify the search key
with a value that consists of an object of type
referencing an array containing one or more elements of type
(the persistent references), and a return-type key of
whose value is
. The objects in the provided array must all be of the same type.
When you use Xcode to create an application, Xcode adds an
entitlement to the application bundle. Keychain Services uses this entitlement to grant the application access to its own keychain items. You can also add a
to the application, specifying an array of keychain access groups to which the application belongs. When you call the
function to add an item to the keychain, you can specify the access group to which that item should belong. By default, the
function searches all the access groups to which the application belongs. However, you can add the
key to the search dictionary to specify which access group to search for keychain items.
blocks the calling thread, so it can cause your app’s UI to hang if called from the main thread. Instead, call
from a background dispatch queue or
function:

code: func findKeychainItem(attributes attrs: CFDictionaryRef, _ completion: @escaping (OSStatus, CFTypeRef?) -> Void) {

abstract.text: The identifiers for the keychain groups that the app may share items with.
A reference to an immutable array object.
A reference to an immutable CFData object.
Boolean true value.
Secure the data your app manages, and control access to your app.
An abstract Core Foundation-type object representing an X.509 certificate.
An abstract Core Foundation-type object representing an identity.
Adds one or more items to a keychain.
Indicates that the item is a generic password.
Indicates that the item is an Internet password.
Returns one or more keychain items that match a search query, or copies attributes of specific keychain items.
An object that represents a cryptographic key.
An opaque type that represents a keychain.
An opaque type that represents a keychain item.
Add network credentials to the keychain on behalf of the user.

doc://com.apple.security/documentation/S.title: Adding a password to the keychain

abstract.text: Specify the class of a keychain item.
Specify how you want returned keychain item data formatted.
A key with a value that’s a string indicating the access group the item is in.
A key whose value indicates a list of items to search.
A key whose value indicates the match limit.
A value that corresponds to matching an unlimited number of items.
A key whose value indicates a list of items to search.
A key whose value is a Boolean that indicates whether or not to return item data.
A key whose value is a Boolean indicating whether or not to return a reference to an item.
Filter a keychain item search.
Find keychain items based on search criteria that you specify.
Evaluate result codes common to many Security framework functions.
Enable apps to share keychain items with each other by adding the apps to an access group.

doc://com.apple.security/documentation/S.title: Sharing access to keychain items among a collection of apps

abstract.text: Store a certificate in the keychain for safekeeping.

doc://com.apple.security/documentation/S.title: Storing a Certificate in the Keychain

abstract.text: Store and access cryptographic keys in the keychain.
Modify items in the keychain when the user’s data changes.
A reference to an immutable dictionary object.
An untyped "generic" reference to any Core Foundation object.
A pointer for accessing and manipulating data of a specific type.
